DOC.HEAD: Slain Federal Judge Eulogized Under Tight Security
With AM-Mail Bombs-Jacksonville, Bjt
LaserPhoto XBM3
DOC.TEXT: Bomb-sniffing dogs and squadrons of police provided tight security Wednesday as a crowd of mourners paid their respects to a federal appeals judge killed by the first in a series of mail bombs. St. Luke's Episcopal Church was filled to overflowing with more than 700 people who were asked to put aside their anger over the slaying long enough to remember the contributions of U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance. Dogs searched the church before the service, and dozens of officers kept watch during the 35-minute program of scripture, hymns and a eulogy. Vance, a member of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court and a former chairman of the Alabama Democratic Party, was killed instantly last Saturday when the bomb exploded in his home, propelling nails into his lower abdomen. His wife, Helen, was injured in the bombing and remained hospitalized Wednesday. A similar bomb two days later killed a civil rights lawyer in Savannah, Ga., City Alderman Robert Robinson. A package bomb was found in the Atlanta courthouse including the 11th Circuit on Monday and a fourth mailed bomb was removed Tuesday from the NAACP headquarters in Jacksonville, Fla. All four targets can be linked to school desegregation efforts by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, leading investigators to speculate that a white racist group may be responsible. Four anonymous letters mailed in August to declare war on various federal appeals courts are being examined for clues to the bombings, FBI spokesman Greg Jones said Wednesday in Washington. The bombs and threats has prompted the NAACP to boost security at its offices, executive director Benjamin Hooks said Wednesday at the organization's national headquarters in Baltimore. Hooks said he's convinced the bombs were the work of white supremacists who feel threatened by recent victories for blacks in courtrooms and at the polls. ``I think it's the work of white supremacists, without any question. I think it reveals the derangement, demented, criminally stupid minds,'' he said. Leaders of the Ku Klux Klan are denying any involvement. ``There ain't nobody in any white supremacist group got sense enough to make a bomb,'' said Daniel B. Carver, Georgia grand dragon of the Invisible Empire Knights of the Ku Klux Klan. ``I'm hoping if it's one of those big drug dealers, maybe they'll take credit for it and get the FBI off our backs.'' Carver was one of several defendants who had appealed a $950,000 jury verdict against two Klan groups for pelting civil rights marchers with rocks and bottles in Forsyth County. The 11th Circuit refused in October to rehear the defendants' appeal. At Vance's service, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Clifford Fulford of Birmingham, a close friend of Vance, delivered the eulogy, asking the mourners to ``put aside our outrage for awhile'' to honor Vance. ``The assassins were cheated if they thought that Bob Vance was afraid to die,'' Fulford said. He described the 58-year-old Vance as a strong believer in the law and a man ``who stood up for the underdog and the oppressed.'' ``No wonder his assassins could not stand such a man in their presence.'' Friends of the Vance family said his remains have been cremated and his ashes will be placed in the church. Because of the rash of bombs, and the attendance of public officials, the church, south of Birmingham, was surrounded by police barriers and cordoned off with yellow tape. Among those who attended the service were Sessions, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy, the justice who oversees the operations of the 11th Circuit, which handles appeals from Floria, Georgia and Alabama.
